Blind Trust is a game about working with someone you can barely communicate with, making for an amazing expirience. Although the game is short, it makes up for that with incredible gameplay, and a proof of concept that I hope inspires more people to create games that provide this sort of expirience.

If you play this game, I would highly recommend turning off any and all communcation software to make sure you get the most immersion possible. If not, just don't give any hints or commands to the other person that could make the expirience worse. If you're in the same room as the person you're playing with, then don't let any possible frustration with the Oracle show through to the other person. On the (slightly) bad side, there are a few glitches in the game, but they have been addressed by the developers, so if you follow their instruction, nothing should go wrong.

If you just want a short amazing game for you and a friend, download this game. You have nothing to lose, since the game is free, so just play it!

reviewText:
I'm writing this review because the only other time(s) I'm gonna play it are to get the last two achievements, and to show a friend or two the game firsthand. Don't get me wrong: I love the game, but it is on the short side, and isn't something you can play endlessly over and over again. (I have 27 minutes logged from playing both characters once)

This game has an amazing idea in play. The deaf leading the blind, and vice-versa in situations. For a free to play title, and despite its short length, I'm very impressed with this game. You choose either the deaf Soldier who can see, but cannot hear a thing (armed with a crossbow), or you choose the blind Oracle who can hear, but cannot see (armed with a spell-casting staff). The Soldier leads the Oracle through the level using a beacon that's mute to him, but emits a distinct sound to the Oracle. You solve puzzles together that involve the Soldier leading the Oracle to the puzzle to activate it together, but be wary as there are invisible monsters in the game that only the Oracle can hear to which they must zap it in order to reveal its location for the Soldier to kill. Upon death, the monsters drop gate keys only the Oracle can pick up that open gates to advance the level.

Like I said, this game is very short, but enjoyable in this concept. If they added random level generation, the replayability of this game would soar. However, I recommend this game to anyone who has a buddy to play with (over LAN/Hamachi, etc) that's intrigued by the game's mechanics. It's free, so there's really not a whole lot you can complain about. Glitches? Maybe some clipping issues in the level, but nothing game-breaking to be honest.

Well, what are you waiting for? Give this little gem a go!

reviewText:
Product received for free

It was a unique concept executed well!

You can either play a blind oracle, who has to use their hearing to know where to go (as well as hearing nearby monsters), and uses a magic staff to reveal the monster to the soldier, or a deaf soldier, who uses a crossbow, attacks the monsters, and lays down audible trackers for the oracle to follow. I played oracle first, than warrior, and I have to say, it was stressful as oracle, aha.

My friend and I used Hamachi to play and it works perfectly fine! We did have some issues trying to connect a game, but after closing the program and relaunching, it was fine. We had no trouble with the tutorial, and if you guys have trouble running hamachi, feel free to comment and ask.

The graphics are stylized but still beautiful, and the little music there was pretty (I launch the game just to listen to the music, honestly). I personally really like the title menu music. The game doesn't have much of a plot, but whatever does happen really makes me curious. Why did a blind oracle and deaf soldier come to this island? What are these paintings on the cave walls? Does anyone still live on this island? Why are the monsters invisible unless revealed by magic? What exactly is the thing at the end? Who knows, honestly.

However, I really enjoyed the game, despite how short it was. If there was a paid game based on this concept and these characters with plot and etc, I would honestly buy it.
